The secondary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 11.84%. The tertiary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 71.97%. In the Cretan delicatessen, Xinochontros (Ksinochondros), the traditional frumeny, keeps an important role both in terms of taste and nutritional value. Xinochontros combines the protein from milk and the unprocessed carbohydrates of wheat. In the past, wheat was grounded in a hand mill, an essential tool for every household. Sour milk is the product obtained by mixing sour milk and fat. Anogeia is located in north-eastern slopes of Psiloritis. The high reputation of Xinochontros in Crete makes the VC of high importance for the people in the wider area of Anogeia. The product is strongly connected to the area due to its land morphology and the high quality of milk (sheep and goats). Xinochontros is a traditional product that was a key component of the household economy which in recent years due to their multiple-use has acquired business interest. For this reason today it is produced with modern methods and procedures by small dairy factories. Such a small dairy factory in Anogeia contributes, distributes and promotes sour cream with significant social, cultural and economic benefit for the wider area. The product is distributed to a significant degree through the local networking and the reputation of the product all over Crete. New marketing strategies involve the promotion of the product through gastronomic events and TV shows. The land use for animal breeding (sheep and goats) is predominant in an area with close proximity to the forest of Rouvas. The SES of the area depends on a series of activites based on livestock, which interconect with the production of xinochondros, an integral part of the diet of the mountaineers of Crete and a favourite ingredient of the Cretan cuisine. Livestock in the wider area of Anogeia focuses mainly on dairy sheep and goats breeds, although the traditional sheep/goat breading has become economically unprofitable and heavily dependent on the European subcidies. Ksinochondros, a relatively high priced product, can give a prospect to the graziers. It is a traditional product, not well known in the new generation of consumers. The high quality of milk in combination with high quality of local wheat create a unique product which could be called as super food. Overall the type of challenge faced by this VC is Current and Predicted. This VC is classified as Traditional and Innovative. The type of innovation of this VC (Value Chain) is Endogenous. The innovation refers to the characteristics of sour cream, a product with high shelf life, low production costs, high nutritional value from local resources. In addition to its close connection with local productions in the wider region and mainly in the economic impact of the product in the region. Lately ksinochondros has penetrated in the gastronomy of Greece as a traditional alternative to cereals in breakfast. The innovation is related to New products, New processes and New marketing strategies. The land use systems involved are Grassland, Forestry and Natural land. The local assets include Natural, social and cultural. Xinochontros (ksinochondros) is produced in several places in Crete."

Risposta: "<think>
Alright, so I need to figure out if the mountain value chain described here is involved in producing cheese with a Protected Designation of Origin (PDO) certification. Let me start by reading through the narrative carefully.

Promp: "ID Narrative: 2826

They organise courses, events exhibitions in permaculture, sustainable water management, building, etc. where they charge participants for the knowledge and the food too (made of their own products). They are creating an online knowledge platform for sharing environmental- and community friendly technology (both innovative and traditional). This VC is classified as Innovative.   The type of innovation of this VC (Value Chain) is Endogenous. The VC is innovative, because it transforms known old knowledge into modern technologies that are easy to use today. VC is both endogenous and exogenous because it is done by inmigrants, moved to the area from outside, but is based entirely on local conditions. They imply solar energy during production and processing and use social networks and ICT for marketing.   The VC uses the natural resources of the area, they cultivate a pumpkin plantation to produce raw material for the pumpkin seed oil and also produce herbs. The cooperation within the village, the support of the local authority, the local human resources are cornerstones of the project. They have become part of the local territorial quality assurance system.    Challenges in connection with climate change (draughts, extreme weather events, etc.) and the potentially less yield due to these issues. Difficulties of working with disadvantaged social groups and continouosly changing policy environment. Overall the type of challenge faced by this VC is Current and Predicted. This VC is classified as Traditional and Innovative.   The type of innovation of this VC (Value Chain) is Endogenous and Exogenous. The municipality s program provides jobs for locals and produces high-quality products that are sold through both short and long supply chains. They use solar energy for drying. The design of the products is beautiful and demanding. The project is the mayor's initiative and is implemented with the locals - the innovation is endogenous. However, the financial support that enabled the process was coming from the government, through an employment programme. The innovation is related to New products, New processes, New marketing strategies and New governance systems. The land use systems involved are Cropland. The local assets include Natural, social and cultural.   The initiative is part of the local territorial quality mark system."

The maximum altimetry of the LAU is unspecified. The total population (in thousand) is 0.989. The population density (Inhabitants/km2) in the LAU is 0.03. The population change rate of the LAU in the last 10 years (%) has been 0.10%. The overall regional population density (Inhabitants/km2) is 61.83. The regional population change rate in the last 10 years (%) has been -0.08%.   The average per capita income (EUR/year) [Province] is 3655. The total Gross Value Added (GVA) (EUR million/year) [Province] is 3098. The primary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 8.46%. The secondary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 15.27%. The tertiary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 76.28%. The per capita income (EUR/year) [Region] is 9034. The total Gross Value Added (GVA) (EUR million/year) [Region] is 7657. The primary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 9.47%. The secondary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 16.43%. The tertiary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 74.10%.   The total number of bed places (BPs) in tourist accommodations/year in the LAU (Local Administrative Unit) is 1723.56. The regional (Region) share of total BPs/year is 10.19%. The number of agricultural holdings in the LAU is 18. The nearest settlement with population over 100000 (km) is 18. In this region protected areas are present.   The primary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 7.74%. The secondary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 32.35%. The tertiary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 59.91%. The primary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 7.74%. The secondary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 32.35%. The tertiary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 59.91%.   A rural museum with guided tours where you can see a grain grinder, a paper mill and oil mill (water-powered / horsepower dry mill). There is a bakery using flowers produced in the mill. There is a reception building and a café, where they sell the delicacies of their bakery, organize one or more day mini-festivals, concerts and workshops. In their graphic workshop, they make custom-designed, hand-screened T-shirts and canvas bags. The innovation here is the well designed interpretation of past culture in a 'working museum'.   The Mill museum is located in a beautiful natural environment with lakes and forests, a prime tourism destination in the area attracting many people. Also, they use the water for the milling, old, but beautifully refurbished agri-industrial buildings, old but revived knowledge, cultural and working traditions.    It is difficult to find employees for these traditional activities (millers, bakers, maintaining traditional wooden mill equipment, etc.), there is labour shortage. It is not easy to find good quality grains for the mill. Their social media and other elctronic marketing platforms need development. They have no visitors during the pandemic. The maintenance of the many buildings and equipment, and producing enough income from their activities is a continouos challenge. They have won various project supports from different EU sources, to realise those projects (prefinancing, administration, etc.) is also s challenge. Overall the type of challenge faced by this VC is Current and Predicted. This VC is classified as Traditional and Innovative.   The type of innovation of this VC (Value Chain) is unspecified. The interactive, working mill museum makes a bridge between the past and the present, explores, preserves, recreates and makes available knowledge of traditional agricultural technology and lifestyle for the present and future generations. The physical space uses past agro-knowledge to help sensitize and change attitudes to social and ecological problems. The innovation is related to The innovation here is the well designed interpretation of past culture in a 'working museum'. The land use systems involved are Old agricultural processing buildings using hidroenergy. The local assets include Natural and cultural."

Promp: "ID Narrative: 2832
The MOVING reference member state of this VC (Value Chain) is HUNGARY. The reference MOVING Card ID of this VC is VC 07 HU. It is part of an exceptionally well designed high value added local products' cluster, run by a monastery, mixing thousand year tradition with modern design and marketing tools, selling history and culture (it is an UNESCO World Heritage site) as much as products. Chocolate and biscuits using locally produced herbs, honey, etc. processed, packaged and marketed with innovative design. Most of the production is organic. They use the profit made through local products for maintaining natural and cultural heritage and supporting social and religious aims.   The reference mountain chain of this VC is Transdanubian mountains. The reference mountain landscape of this VC is Pannonhalma. Pannonhalma is a small town of 3000 inhabitants, having a 1100 years old benedict monastery. It is a low mountain area, at the north of the Bakony mountains in the west of Hungary near the Austrian border.   The size of the area (km2) is 30. The minimum altimetry of the LAU (Local Administrative Unit) is 271. The maximum altimetry of the LAU is unspecified. The total population (in thousand) is 4.064. The population density (Inhabitants/km2) in the LAU is 135.47. The population change rate of the LAU in the last 10 years (%) has been 0.04%. The overall regional population density (Inhabitants/km2) is 95.45. The regional population change rate in the last 10 years (%) has been -0.04%.   The average per capita income (EUR/year) [Province] is 3877. The total Gross Value Added (GVA) (EUR million/year) [Province] is 3286. The primary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 4.99%. The secondary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 27.78%. The tertiary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 67.22%. The per capita income (EUR/year) [Region] is 14578. The total Gross Value Added (GVA) (EUR million/year) [Region] is 12355. The primary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 4.78%. The secondary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 38.97%. The tertiary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 56.24%.   The total number of bed places (BPs) in tourist accommodations/year in the LAU (Local Administrative Unit) is 125.1. The regional (Region) share of total BPs/year is 10.03%. The number of agricultural holdings in the LAU is 115. The nearest settlement with population over 100000 (km) is 22. In this region protected areas are present.   The primary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 4.47%. The secondary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 42.86%. The tertiary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 52.67%. The primary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 4.47%. The secondary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 42.86%. The tertiary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 52.67%.   It is part of an exceptionally well designed high value added local products' claster, run by a monastery, mixing thousand year tradition with modern design and marketing tools, selling history and culture (it is an UNESCO World Heritage site) as much as products. These particular products are innovative and special. Chocolate and biscuits are reasonably new products for the monastery, especially using traditionally produced herbs (levander, thyme, etc.) to make the products special. Packaging and the presentation of the products is also really high quality and innovative. The marketing of the whole products' cluster is based on 'selling the 1000 year history' of the place, all products are made to appear a mixture of tradition and innovation. The UNESCO World heritage status of the monastery is also used effectively in marketing.   The monastery has some 60 ha of land, including a herb garden. They have a well documented history of their own agricultural production (products, stories, etc.) for a 1000 years, this knowledge is used in production and marketing effectively. The managers of the different sections, products (the herb garden, winery, brewery, fruit and vegetable gardens, local shop, design, marketing, etc.) are normally having some strong ties to the monastery (e.g. monks, or graduated from the secondary school of the monastery, etc.) Staff is normally very committed, loyal and strongly identifies with the place and the community. Being a UNESCO World heritage site also helps.    Providing income for the religious and educative activities of the monastery, based on very limited land (the monastery used to have thousands of hectares of land compared to some 50-60 ha today). Harmonising tradition and innovation, finding new ways of marketing, products, design, etc. Overall the type of challenge faced by this VC is Current and Predicted. This VC is classified as Traditional and Innovative.   The type of innovation of this VC (Value Chain) is Endogenous and Exogenous. These products are part of a complex claster, including many products, tourist attractions, etc. Chocolate and biscuits using locally produced herbs, honey, etc. processed, packaged and marketed with innovative design. The innovation is related to New products, New processes and New marketing strategies. The land use systems involved are Cropland and Forestry. The local assets include Natural, social and cultural.   An UNESCO world heritage site, where respect for traditional natural and cultural values is very succesfully coupled with modern design and marketing in the framework of a local products and tourism claster."

Handicraft products made in the herbal workshop of the Archabbey of Pannonhalma Officina Sancti Martini. The innovation is related to New products, New processes and New marketing strategies. Traditional production of potato with special local varieties, produced by small farmers, integrated by one larger ones, marketed through both short and long supply chains (in Hungary and abroad). SES - maintain traditional, more sustainable ways of production, rural lifestyle, landscape. Producing high quality, sustainable food.   The reference mountain chain of this VC is Transdanubian mountains. The reference mountain landscape of this VC is Olaszfalu. Olaszfalu is a small village (municipality), in Veszprém county, belonging to a small town Zirc, with reasonably good road and railway connections. It is situated in a valley with good alluvial soils, wet and cool weather, surrounded by large forested areas.   The size of the area (km2) is 43. The minimum altimetry of the LAU (Local Administrative Unit) is 486. The maximum altimetry of the LAU is unspecified. The total population (in thousand) is 1.053. The average per capita income (EUR/year) [Province] is 3877. The total Gross Value Added (GVA) (EUR million/year) [Province] is 3286. The primary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 4.99%. The secondary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 27.78%. The tertiary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 67.22%. The per capita income (EUR/year) [Region] is 14578. The secondary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 42.86%. The tertiary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 52.67%.   Successful local integration of small traditional potato producers by a slightly larger local producer, who organises logistics, storage, processing and trading of the products. They have become part of the local territorial quality assurance system (European Territorial Quality Mark). Potato is a very traditional product for mountain agriculture in the region, however traditional producers are on the verge of extintion due to marketing problems and large scale competition. The only way forward seems to be integration, of which this is an excellent example.   Very good conditions (weather, soil) and a long cultural tradition of cabbage production. The presence of human capacity to organise logistics and achieve economies of scale. Available technology for storage and logistics (based on a 'recicled processing and storage plant of a multi-national company) Good connections with the local LEADER LAG, organising marketing and community action.    Difficult communication between producers, finding markets, challenges in connection with climate change (draughts, extreme weather events, etc.), maintaining interest of producers in participating in the local producers' networks, etc. Overall the type of challenge faced by this VC is Current and Predicted. This VC is classified as Traditional.   The type of innovation of this VC (Value Chain) is unspecified. An indigenous local producer managed to integrate small producers in and around the municipality, create the necessary high technology infrastructure for logistics and storage and create a considerable volume from a traditional product, enough to approach larger markets. + participation in the ETQM - social innovation, etc. The innovation is related to the whole VC. The land use systems involved are Cropland. The local assets include Natural, social and cultural."

Promp: "ID Narrative: 2836
The MOVING reference member state of this VC (Value Chain) is HUNGARY. The reference MOVING Card ID of this VC is VC 11 HU. Logging for firewood, sawmill and nearby thermal power plant. Replantation and maintenance of the forest. Typical and traditional mountain activity, complemented with building and maintaining tourist routes, resting places, watch towers, etc. Workers employed in forestry are often disadvantaged, poor people, not having other possibilities for income, thus forestry is important for social reasons. Well managed forest provides for biodiversity.   The reference mountain chain of this VC is Transdanubian mountains. The reference mountain landscape of this VC is Zirc. The town of Zirc in Veszprém county is the only town in the Zirc district and its center, the 'capital of the Bakony'. It is the highest town in Hungary (the 400-meter level line passes through the city center). Zirc has not only road but also rail access.   The size of the area (km2) is 37. The MOVING reference member state of this VC (Value Chain) is HUNGARY. The reference MOVING Card ID of this VC is VC 14 HU. In the Bakony Mountains, there are many people involved in beekeeping, some who started it 50 years ago, some in recent years. Olaszfalu is a small village (municipality), in Veszprém county, belonging to a small town Zirc, with reasonably good road and railway connections. It is situated in a valley with good alluvial soils, wet and cool weather, surrounded by large forested areas.   The size of the area (km2) is 43. The secondary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 42.86%. The tertiary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 52.67%.   In the Bakony Mountains, there are many people involved in beekeeping, some who started it 50 years ago, some in recent years, migrating with the bees, following the blossoming of different plants and trees. These beekeepers are members of European Territorial Quality Mark Bakonyi Local Brand trademark. Their products are sold through short supply chains with some common design. They participate in a joint marketing system and are members of the European Territorial Quality Mark: Bakonyi Local Brand. It is also a quality assurance system and a marketing tool to promote products with a common logo. The trademark also creates cooperation between producers. They also produce special honey types: lavender honey, shallot honey, chestnut honey, hawthorn honeyf and special flavored honeys (walnut honey, hazelnut honey, herbal honey).   Very good condition and a long cultural tradition of honey production, large forested and agricultural areas. Good co-operation with agricultural producers (they are most happy to accept the bees on their land). Good connections with the local LEADER LAG, organising marketing and community action.    Mainly bee pests and diseases, as well as the effects of climate change, are also causing chemical treatments associated with industrial crop production. Fewer and fewer people choose beekeeping as a profession. For big companies honey can be sold at low prices, but a lot of energy needs to be invested in short supply chains. Many of the beekeepers are ageing, they stop selling in small scale and they often do not have anyone to pass the profession (and their bees) on. Overall the type of challenge faced by this VC is Current and Predicted. This VC is classified as Traditional and Innovative.   The type of innovation of this VC (Value Chain) is Endogenous and Exogenous. Honey itself is considered traditional in this field, but demanding packaging, quality, and often online sales through a short supply chain are considered innovative. Many of the beekeepers are locals, but others are lifestile entrepreneur incommers, bringing new knowledge, technology, etc. to the common pool. The innovation is related to New products and New marketing strategies. The land use systems involved are Cropland, grassland and forestry. The local assets include Natural and cultural."

The narrative doesn't mention any such details about the cheese production process or any certifications like PDO.

The mountain value chain described does not appear to be involved in the production of cheese with Protected Designation of Origin (PDO) certification.

**Step-by-Step Explanation:**

2. **Analyzing the Narrative:** The VC focuses on truffle collection, processed products (including cheese), and tourism. While they make cheese-based products, there's no mention of specific traditional methods or regional regulations tied to PDO.

4. **Conclusion:** Without evidence of PDO-eligible production methods or recognition, the VC isn't involved in PDO-certified cheese production.

Promp: "ID Narrative: 2849
The MOVING reference member state of this VC (Value Chain) is ITALY UNIMOL and UNIPI. The reference MOVING Card ID of this VC is VC 01 IT. Parmigiano Reggiano DOP is an hard cheese of ancient tradition, handcrafted with raw cow's milk, partially skimmed by surfacing, without adding additives or preservatives but only rennet; the product can undergo a seasoning that goes from 12 months onwards.   The reference mountain chain of this VC is Northern Apennines - Tuscan-Emilian Apennines. The reference mountain landscape of this VC is Palanzano. Palanzano is a municipality in the Province of Parma, Emilia-Romagna region, found about 55 kilometres south of chief city Parma. It is located in the Parma Apennines, on the slopes of Faggeto Mount, in the upper Cedra valley, between meadows and chestnut woods.   The size of the area (km2) is 69.8. The minimum altimetry of the LAU (Local Administrative Unit) is 351. The maximum altimetry of the LAU is 1550. The total population (in thousand) is 1.086. The population density (Inhabitants/km2) in the LAU is 15.55. The population change rate of the LAU in the last 10 years (%) has been -11.49%. The overall regional population density (Inhabitants/km2) is 198.61. The regional population change rate in the last 10 years (%) has been 3.44%.   The average per capita income (EUR/year) [Province] is 38700. The total Gross Value Added (GVA) (EUR million/year) [Province] is 15648.6. The primary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 2.38%. The secondary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 36.11%. The tertiary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 61.49%. The per capita income (EUR/year) [Region] is 36200. The total Gross Value Added (GVA) (EUR million/year) [Region] is 144710. The primary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 2.51%. The secondary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 31.47%. The tertiary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 66.02%.   The total number of bed places (BPs) in tourist accommodations/year in the LAU (Local Administrative Unit) is 24. The regional (Region) share of total BPs/year is 0.01%. The number of agricultural holdings in the LAU is 56. The nearest settlement with population over 100000 (km) is 55. In this region protected areas are not present.   The primary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 2.78%. The secondary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 30.59%. The tertiary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 66.63%. The primary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 3.06%. The secondary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 28.03%. The tertiary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 68.91%.   Parmigiano Reggiano is produced with milk from the area of origin, natural rennet, salt and no additives, in an artisanal way, in about 350 small dairies in the typical area and about 3500 milk farmers-producers who have obtained the recognition to preserve unchanged the processing method and the very high quality level. These farm use the certification ' Mountain Product' Reg.(UE) n.1151/2012 and Reg.(UE) n.665/2014. Parmigiano Reggiano is one of the most famous italian production, The selection of parmigiano reggiano product in mountain want to valorise a product and the territories of production.   Parmigiano Reggiano POD mountain product, is stepped in the tradition and history of a small, thought abundantly diverse territory. Everything takes places on a specific area of Apennines mountain range, from the growing of animal fodder to the breeding of the cows that produce the milk used to make the cheese. The meadows are self regenerating fields, because they have not been plowed, in same cases, not even centuries. They protected the land and are a place of biodiversity, yielding up more than 60 different fodder types that are the key aspect for the cheese quality.    Pursuing the aims of the consortium, which concern the protection of the PDO of 'Parmigiano Reggiano' cheese, the supervision of production and trade, and the promotion of production in Italy and abroad, they can be further enhanced, increasing its image and notoriety in the world. Overall the type of challenge faced by this VC is Current. This VC is classified as Traditional.   The type of innovation of this VC (Value Chain) is unspecified. 'Mountain product' represents a quality of Parmigiano Reggiano that must be subject to additional rules concerning not only the geographical origin, but also the diet, the breeding of the cows and the aging of the cheese. The innovation is related to the whole VC. The land use systems involved are Cropland, Grassland and Natural land. The local assets include Natural and cultural.   The production area includes the provinces of Parma, Reggio Emilia, Modena, Bologna to the left of the Reno river and Mantua to the south of the Po river. For certification as a Mountain Product, ie produced in the Apennine areas: - 100% milk from stables in mountain areas. - More than 60% of the cows' feed grown in the mountain area. - Dairy and maturing up to 12 months minimum, in the mountain area."

Risposta: "<think>
Alright, so I need to figure out if the given narrative about a mountain value chain is involved in producing cheese with PDO certification. Let me start by reading through the narrative carefully.

The narrative mentions that the reference member state is Italy, specifically UNIMOL and UNIPI. The Value Chain (VC) has a reference card ID of VC 01 IT. It talks about Parmigiano Reggiano DOP, which I know is a well-known cheese with PDO certification. So right off the bat, that's a clue.

The mountain chain involved here is the Northern Apennines - Tuscan-Emilian Apennines, and the specific location mentioned is Palanzano, a municipality in Emilia-Romagna region near Parma. Parmigiano Reggiano is produced in this area, which aligns with what I know about PDO cheeses needing to be from a specific geographical region.

The narrative goes into detail about how the cheese is made: using raw cow's milk, handcrafted without additives or preservatives, just rennet. It also mentions that the product can undergo seasoning for at least 12 months. This traditional method of production is typical of PDO products, which have strict regulations on ingredients and processes.

Further down, it specifies that Parmigiano Reggiano DOP is a mountain product under EU regulations (UE) n.1151/2012 and n.665/2014. These are the regulations forPDO andPGI products, so this directly ties the cheese to having PDO certification.

The narrative also talks about the production process involving specific areas of the Apennine mountain range, from fodder growth to cow breeding and cheese aging, all within the mountain area. This adherence to geographical and traditional methods is another indicator that it's a PDO product.

Additionally, the consortium mentioned is focused on protecting the PDO status, supervising production and trade, and promoting the cheese both domestically and internationally. All these aspects are consistent with how PDO products are managed to maintain their quality and origin.

Putting this all together, the narrative clearly describes the production of Parmigiano Reggiano DOP, which has PDO certification. The involvement of specific regulations, traditional methods, and geographical specificity all point towards the mountain value chain being involved in producing a cheese with PDO certification.

Chestnut flour is produced by secular chestnut tree planted from 500 meters to 1000 meter that usually rapresent the highest altitude, The Chestnuts are collected by small farm that process the fruit in small productions and high identity value. The chestnut tree performs various functions: productive, protective, naturalistic, landscape, recreational, didactic. The innovation start to spread also in this very traditional value chain. The interest for chestnut flour is come back after several years of total abandon of chestnut tree. In the area ther is a general lack of professionalism. There is a very small supply compare with a very hight demand with a willing to pay very high prices. There is some local business association that try to change the local situation. Honey bees are crucial for maintaining biodiversity because they pollinate numerous plant species that require an obligatory pollinator for fertilisation and they are useful to maintain a diversificate landscape. Alright, so I need to figure out if the mountain value chain described in narrative ID 2853 is involved in producing cheese with PDO certification. Let me go through the information step by step.

First, the narrative mentions that the Di Nucci family dairy produces typical local cheese, specifically Caciocavallo cheese.PDO stands for Protected Designation of Origin, which means the cheese must be produced in a specific region using traditional methods and meet certain quality standards.

Looking at the details, the dairy is described as an old family company from 1662, emphasizing local raw materials and fair collaboration with breeders who supply milk under high-quality and environmental sustainability standards. They also highlight their marketing strategy that connects the product to the cultural and rural traditions of Alto Molise, including practices like transhumance.

Caciocavallo cheese is a well-known Italian cheese, and I recall that it does have PDO certification. The production is typically associated with specific regions in Italy, such as Molise, which aligns with the location mentioned here (Alto Molise). Additionally, the emphasis on traditional methods and local materials further supports the likelihood of PDO certification.

The narrative also mentions that the dairy has quality certifications and has won awards for their products and strategies. While not explicitly stating PDO, the context strongly suggests it, especially sincePDO is common for such traditional cheeses in Italy.

Therefore, I conclude that this mountain value chain is indeed involved in producing cheese with PDO certification.

This farm produces potatos in the Sardinian mountains.In the recent years, the owners have start to process potatos using an innovative recipe to produce cookies called ' cioccoterra'. The farm took the opportunity offered by Reg.(UE) n.1151/2012 and Reg.(UE) n.665/2014 to use the label ' Mountain Product'. In Sardinia the used agricultural area for potato production is about 3000 ha ( source' Piano di settore pataticolo MIPAAF'), which represents only 4% of national surface. however, potato from Sardinia has a relevant quality and it is specialised in early potatos that are sold on market before other potatos varieties. Overall the type of challenge faced by this VC is unspecified. This VC is classified as N/A.   The type of innovation of this VC (Value Chain) is unspecified. The idea to use potatos for cookies production came from Mp Sardinia (https://www.mpsardinia.it/), a Sardinian agricultural company located in Buddusò, and managed by the Pischedda brothers. The cookie is called 'Cioccoderra', a chocolate praline with a dark shell filled with potato cream. Two varieties of potatoes are used to make this delicacy: the purple potato, and the traditional yellow one. The floury dough of the first variety, and the slightly compact dough of the second one make these potatoes particularly suitable for pastry making. In order to be able to eliminate the water content and keep their density, it is combined with the delight of cocoa, butter and sugar, without using any preservatives. The innovation is related to the whole VC. The land use systems involved are N/A. The local assets include N/A."

Risposta: "<think>

The narrative talks about a farm called MP Sardinia located in the Altopiano di Buddusò region of Sardinia. Their main business is potato production, but they also make 'cioccoderra' cookies during holidays like Christmas and Easter. These cookies are made using two types of potatoes: purple and yellow. The description mentions that they use innovative recipes to create these cookies, which are a type of pastry filled with potato cream and praline.

Nowhere in the narrative is there any mention of cheese production. They focus on potatoes and their derivative products like the cookies. PDO certification typically applies to products like cheeses (e.g., Parmigiano-Reggiano, Roquefort) where specific regional ingredients and methods are crucial for quality and origin. Since the value chain here is centered around potatoes and not dairy or cheese, it doesn't seem involved in cheese production.

Additionally, the narrative references EU regulations 1151/2012 and 665/2014 regarding 'Mountain Product' labels, but these are applied to their potato-based cookies, not cheese. There's no indication that they're producing any dairy products or seeking PDO certification for cheese.

So, based on the information provided, this mountain value chain isn't involved in cheese production with PDO certification.
</think>

There is no mention of cheese production or any involvement with Protected Designation of Origin (PDO) certification for cheese. Therefore, it does not qualify.

Fabriano is considered as a very important industrial pole in Marche region. Fabriano is known for the paper manufacturing sector (there is an historical local tradition of paper mills) and for the household appliance industry of important Italian brands. The number of agricultural holdings in the LAU is 572. The nearest settlement with population over 100000 (km) is 60. In this region protected areas are present.   The primary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 2.13%. The secondary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 28.25%. The tertiary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 69.62%. The primary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 2.97%. The secondary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 31.23%. The tertiary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 65.80%.   A young farmer's son decides to produce high quality, organic honey by partly innovating his production with barrel-aged honey and distilling mead. Most of the honey production is done in the mountain area. The beekeeper establishes commercial collaborations with local activities or located in neighbouring regions, like dairy and catering activities. Barrel-aged honey is an innovative product, just as mead production is not usual. The marketing strategy adopted is based on commercial cooperation that brings together several players from different production chains (dairies, restaurants, etc.).   The farmlands are used to produce peculiar honey (e.g., sunflower honey), while forest areas are used for traditional honey (Acacia honey). The beekeeper's knowledge is applied to improve quality production, invent new products and marketing initiatives.    Climate change is a significant challenge for honey production because of its adverse effects on plants' biological cycles and drought. Climate change also including the need to move hives in higher areas to find certain plant varieties. This practice and put a strain on the bees' ability to resist in colder mountain zones. Overall the type of challenge faced by this VC is Current and Predicted. This VC is classified as Innovative.   The type of innovation of this VC (Value Chain) is Endogenous. The beekeeper wanted to improve his honey with the production of unique honey. He devised the process of ageing the honey in barrels to obtain a product with a special, intense aroma. He also adopted a marketing strategy involving other local agricultural producers (such as dairy farmers) or those in the tourism sector (restaurants) to combine his product with other excellent products and services. The products are also sold online, and the beekeeper has engaged in innovative promotion campaigns on Youtube. The innovation is related to New products, New processes and New marketing strategies. The land use systems involved are Cropland, Forestry and Natural land. The local assets include Natural, social, cultural and Knowledge acquired in educational and professional training together with a personal and amateur passion for beekeeping."

It is located 46 km eastern to Crotone, one of the larger town of the Calabria region, Southern Italy. This family farm enhances the value of a typical mountain product, the chestnut. The chestnut groves are cultivated organically. Some of the processed products are made by local companies that use the Scalise farm's flour chestnut. The farm has a sales point in the town centre of Patilia Policastro. They also use other local products to enlarge their production, such as dessert sauce made by figs (called vincotto di fichi ). Innovation consists of re-proposing products that belong to the mountain tradition in a modern form. The farmer also diversifies the products obtained from processing chestnuts.   Chestnut groves have always been and element of the landscape of the SES and they are cultivated in a sustainable way. The owner of the farm has innovated the family's agricultural activity by revitalising chestnut products in a modern way. Traditional products, partially forgotten, are proposed as an element of cultural heritage to valorize.    Chestnuts are a product with a not large market, and it is necessary to devise new ways to use them (or recovering old use of chestnuts) that the market can appreciate. This entails an increased market risk for the farm. It is also necessary to establish commercial collaboration with other local players, particularly for processing and sales business activities. Moreover, climate change may affect the quality production of chestnut trees. Furthermore, this VC has no peculiar certification to characterize it as a local and traditional high-quality production. Overall the type of challenge faced by this VC is Current and Predicted. This VC is classified as Traditional and Innovative.   The type of innovation of this VC (Value Chain) is Endogenous. A traditional product with a reduced market, the chestnut, is cultivated organically and processed into flour, then used to prepare various products that belong to the mountain tradition (such as chestnut flour bread). The farm owner recovered these productions for a market that appreciates local food and wine traditions and environmental sustainability. Knowledge and skills used are developed locally by the family farm and belonging to the local tradition. The innovation is related to the whole VC. The land use systems involved are Cropland and Forestry. The local assets include Natural and cultural."

Alright, so I need to figure out if the mountain value chain described in narrative ID 2864 is involved in producing cheese with PDO certification. Let me go through the information step by step.

First, the narrative mentions that the reference member state is Italy, specifically UNIMOL and UNIPI. The Value Chain (VC) reference card ID is VC18 IT. The mountain chain is the Northern Apennines - Tuscan Emilian Apennines, with a specific location in Sambuca Pistoiese, Tuscany.

Looking at the details about the Savigni family, they started a butcher's shop and later expanded to include a cured meat factory. They emphasize quality control and have various certifications listed. These include organic certifications like BioAgriCert and AIAB, as well as others such as INEQ for PDO (Protected Designation of Origin) products.

The certificates mentioned are Bollo IT 9-3467/L IT R152E CE ANAS, Japan Export, BioAgriCert, Products Guarantee AIAB, INEQ, TUV, and several quality consortia. Notably, the INEQ certification is specifically for PDO control of Cinta Senese and Finocchiona PGI products.

The narrative also talks about their organic farming practices, outdoor production, and focus on local animals to meet international demand. They mention challenges related to maintaining high-quality supply and entering new markets through certifications.

Now, I'm looking for any mention of cheese production with PDO certification. The certificates listed include several for meat products like Cinta Senese and Finocchiona PGI, but there's no specific mention of cheese. PDO typically applies to both meats and cheeses, so the presence of INEQ as a certification body suggests they might be involved in PDO products, but without explicit mention of cheese.

The focus seems more on cured meats rather than dairy products. The Savigni family's main activities are butchery and cured meat production, not cheese-making. Therefore, even though they have PDO-related certifications, these don't necessarily apply to cheese.

So, based on the information provided, there's no indication that this value chain is involved in producing cheese with PDO certification. They're focused on meat products.

The innovation start in 2014 with the idea of giving value and dignity to one of the humblest agricultural products in our kitchen ( potatos). The innovation is related to New marketing strategies. Promp: "ID Narrative: 2867
The MOVING reference member state of this VC (Value Chain) is ITALY UNIMOL and UNIPI. The reference MOVING Card ID of this VC is VC 24 IT. In the Piacenza province has an average yearly production of 24 million bottles of wine, with an average selling price slightly above 4 €/bottle. The foothill production of Colli Piacentini PDO is able to obtain higher prices, but often barely enough to compensate the greater production costs and the lower yield that are chracteristic of high slope viticulture. There is a strong need in creating added value on wine of the region. The most dynamic situation can be found in Val Nure and Val Trebbia, where all the production is coming from family owned estates, most under organic certified production and used to joint promotional activities. Many wineries in these valleys have already reached high technical quality and outstanding reputation on the national and international markets. In this environment, the elevation toward mountains of the vineyard is a trend that started about 10 years ago with some pioneers, and that is presently taken in consideration by several wineries.   The reference mountain chain of this VC is 0. The reference mountain landscape of this VC is TRAVO. Colli Piacentini is a portion of the Appenninian mountain chain in Northen Italy. The Colli Piacentini ('Hills of Piacenza') is an Italian wine region located at the western end of Emilia-Romagna. In 1967, it was given the Denominazione di origine controllata (DOC) quality designation. Within its boundaries are several smaller DOCs including Colli Piacentini Gutturnio, Monterosso Val D'Arda DOC, Trebbianino Val Trebbia DOC and Val Nure del Colli Piacentini DOC. The region has a long history of winemaking with fossilized vine roots and grape seeds excavated from the region showing viticulture taking place as early as 2000 BC. In Roman times, Julius Caesar's father-in-law Lucius Calpurnius Piso Caesoninus, grew grapes in the Piacenza hills. The Colli Piacentini was once considered part of the Piedmont wine region. To the northwest is the Lombardy wine region of Oltrepò Pavese and, like Oltrepò Pavese, the wine industry of the Colli Piacentini has had strong historical ties to the wine markets of Milan. The region produces over 17 different wines ranging from Vin Santo dessert wines to slightly sparkling frizzante wines. While the practice of labeling wines by varietal is more often associated with New World wines, winemakers in the Colli Piacentini are permitted by DOC regulations to label some of their wines by varietal.   The size of the area (km2) is 81.01. The minimum altimetry of the LAU (Local Administrative Unit) is 122. The maximum altimetry of the LAU is 835. The total population (in thousand) is 2.149. The population density (Inhabitants/km2) in the LAU is 26.53. The population change rate of the LAU in the last 10 years (%) has been 5.30%. The overall regional population density (Inhabitants/km2) is 198.82. The regional population change rate in the last 10 years (%) has been 1.60%.   The average per capita income (EUR/year) [Province] is 18429. The total Gross Value Added (GVA) (EUR million/year) [Province] is 8572. The primary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 3.40%. The secondary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 24.30%. The tertiary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 68.60%. The per capita income (EUR/year) [Region] is 17010. The total Gross Value Added (GVA) (EUR million/year) [Region] is 146732. The primary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 2.40%. The secondary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 31.50%. The tertiary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 66.10%.   The total number of bed places (BPs) in tourist accommodations/year in the LAU (Local Administrative Unit) is 3444. The regional (Region) share of total BPs/year is 12.78%. The number of agricultural holdings in the LAU is 59674. The nearest settlement with population over 100000 (km) is 32. In this region protected areas are present.   The primary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 5.86%. The secondary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 31.76%. The tertiary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 62.38%.   The landscape is representative of many other foothill area of Appenninian chain all along the Italian peninsula. Global warming and depreciation of mountain land are at the basis of an increased interest of viticulturists for higher altitude parcels with respect to the usual vineyard foothill range. In Colli piacentini area the phenomenon is at the very beginning, and not (yet) triggered by famous brands. The process is at its beginning in the region, and it can take profit from the experience of other more advanced mountin regions, as well as be a model for other areas that want to follow the same track.   The area is at about 1 hour driving from the Milan area, one of the most populated and whealty regions in Europe. It is also very well reputed for its gastronomy, especially bases on cured meat and home made pasta. Wine producers are already associated in joined promotional initiatives.    Depopulation, increase in farmer ages, climate change, and higher pruduction costs compared to lowland agriculture are among the causes of a deep crisis of farming activity in the Italian foothill areas. While grape production is already an underpaid activity, wine production creates enough added value to allow reasonable income and sustainable agriculture activity. Overall the type of challenge faced by this VC is Current and Predicted. This VC is classified as Tradiotional and Innovative.   The type of innovation of this VC (Value Chain) is Endogenous and Exogenous. In order to characterize its wine production, the region is working on different axis: - put in value the local grape varieties like Malvasia, Ortrugo, and discover other traditional ancient varieties that return to be interesting for climate change resilience - introduce controlled cover crop in vineyard, finding a balance between the practical advantages of the grass between rows, and the water carency in certain areas and periods - embrace the organic standard of production. The innovation is related to New products, New processes and New governance systems. The land use systems involved are Cropland and Forestry. The local assets include Natural, social and cultural."

For many years potatos were considered as a commodity product with a basic price. Only the last years, to mitigate the reduction of per capita consuption, were introduce new marketing strategies based on the traciability of the product thanks to the valorisation of local productions. By improving the profitability conditions of mountain agri-food production it is possible to generate positive effects on the mountain territory by reducing its depopulation.   The research project, done under the RDP 4 , intends to provide the operators of the 'Montese Potato' value chain with some useful tools to improve the perceived value of their mountain product. In fact, with the adoption of the European brand 'Mountain Product' in conjunction with the 'Patata di Montese' brand, producers can improve the brand awareness of their customers and therefore the perceived value of their products. Furthermore, referring to the product packaging and distribution phase, the project aims to identify the packaging system and coordinate the collaboration with the distribution to increase the penetration of distribution in the points of sale and support producers in the development of appropriate marketing activities. 'Federico Di Iorio' produces high quality confectioneries using traditional recipes but also adding, in some cases, new ingredients. This artisanal factory received several prestigious awards in international trade fairs since the early 1900s (Milan, 1911; Belgium 1923; London, 1925: Brussels, 1939). In that occasion, it was proposed an Easter dove bread made with a dough of 8 cereal flour types and filled with pineapple and chocolate. 'Di Iorio' produces different kinds of confectioneries, and the line 'Vecchia maniera' (the old-fashioned way production) is made with the traditional recipes and only Italian root materials (almonds, sugar, flour, butter, etc.). In the SES, the production of nougat is traditional. However, the 'Di Iorio' factory has diversified its production with other conventional Italian confectionery products and innovated the products more in line with consumers' needs and interests. The company has also invested in online commerce. They stress high-quality productions and their awards.   Gastronomic and confectionery culture is predominant in this VC. Several local products, such as honey, are used for production, but historically other products come from other SESs. Thus the VC connects several SES. However, strong connections with local agricultural production are not stressed.    In the high-quality traditional confectionery sector, innovation and the origin of raw materials are competitive factors. In the case of 'Di Iorio', innovation crosses local (i.e., nougat) and national (panettone, Easter eggs, dove bread, etc.) gastronomic culture. However, the origin of the raw materials is not always local. Although this is not in contradiction with the local tradition (since the Romans time, the SES is connected by trades with distant areas), it may pose a problem in communication strategies. For example, in the case of nougat, traditionally, almonds come from the Apulia region while honey is local. At the same time, in the business communication lacks a link with the local social context and environment settings. Overall the type of challenge faced by this VC is Current and Predicted. This VC is classified as Traditional and Innovative.   The type of innovation of this VC (Value Chain) is Endogenous and Exogenous. In this case 'Di Iorio' experiments with confectionery innovations by combining local and non-local products. Local confectionery production embeds traditional skills and culture with gastronome and confectionery sciences. They also invested in e-commerce for direct sale and opened social profile for direct communication with customers. The innovation is related to New products and New marketing strategies. Promp: "ID Narrative: 2874
The MOVING reference member state of this VC (Value Chain) is ITALY UNIMOL and UNIPI. The reference MOVING Card ID of this VC is VC 36 IT. The cheese is produced only with milk from the 'Podolica' cow which is a local breed. The processing relies on tranditional activities which are mostly performed at the farm. Thus, farmers are the main actors of the VC. The product is mainly sold on-farm or in local markets. 'Caciocavallo dei Monti Dauni' holds the label of 'Traditional Food Italian Product'. For such products a production specification scheme needs to be followed and it dictate that milk only from wilde and semi-wild breed Podolica cows must be use to produce the cheese only using traditional production techniques. For all these reasons, the product is considered an identity of the area.   The reference mountain chain of this VC is Southern Appennines. The reference mountain landscape of this VC is Monteleone di Puglia. Monteleone di Puglia is a hill municipality located in the Sub-Appenines Dauno, it is located in the province of Foggia (Puglia) in an area at the cross-border between Puglia, Basilicata and Campania. The town is located on top of the plateau of eastern 'Irpinia', a district of the Southern Italian Appennines.   The size of the area (km2) is 36.41. The minimum altimetry of the LAU (Local Administrative Unit) is 496. The maximum altimetry of the LAU is 978. The total population (in thousand) is 0.993. The population density (Inhabitants/km2) in the LAU is 27.27272727. The population change rate of the LAU in the last 10 years (%) has been -21.85%. The overall regional population density (Inhabitants/km2) is 206.8. The regional population change rate in the last 10 years (%) has been -2.63%.   The average per capita income (EUR/year) [Province] is 18200. The total Gross Value Added (GVA) (EUR million/year) [Province] is 10181.4. The primary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 9.71%. The secondary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 16.77%. The tertiary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 73.51%. The per capita income (EUR/year) [Region] is 18900. The total Gross Value Added (GVA) (EUR million/year) [Region] is 69423.2. The primary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 4.06%. The secondary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 18.58%. The tertiary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 76.15%.   The total number of bed places (BPs) in tourist accommodations/year in the LAU (Local Administrative Unit) is 26. The regional (Region) share of total BPs/year is 0.01%. The number of agricultural holdings in the LAU is 201. The nearest settlement with population over 100000 (km) is 59. In this region protected areas are not present.   The primary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 14.47%. The secondary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 16.77%. The tertiary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 68.76%. The primary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 9.17%. The secondary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 19.64%. The tertiary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 71.19%.   The Caciocavallo cheese holds the national label of 'Traditional Food Italian Product' and it can be considered an territorial identity of the area. The product valorise a cow breeding ('Podolica') tipical of Southern Italy and it is produced valorizing local traditions and cultural know-how. The connection with the land use system is strong, since the cheese can only be produced by 'Podolica' cows bred through the wild or semi-wild systems. The amount of product available for the market is limited. Thus, besides the local makets and on-farm selling, producers started to exploit alternative marketing strategies to reach larger consumer communities such as e-commerce and on-farm selling connected with hosting activities.   The area is characterised by a higlhy mixed land use system, where forests and natural grassland the dominant land use systems in the interplay with agricultural land. The 'Podolica' cow breed is traditional asset of the Southern Italian regions, characterized by lower milk production compared with intensive cow breed (e.g., Frisona, Pezzata Rossa), but very much suited for breeding through in wild and semi-wilde systems.    The Caciocavallo cheese is produced in a very remote mountain area with a market trait of rurality which is affected by ageing population and depopulation. The remoteness of the area make it difficult for the active part of the population to share formal and informal knowledges and experiences that can promote the valorisation of local natural (busheses, woods, and natural grass land) and human (traditional know-how) resources . Additionaly, intensive agriculture production drastically reduced the areas dedicated to natural land, natural grassland, and thus, the activities connected with traditional livestock activities such as the 'transumanza'. Overall the type of challenge faced by this VC is Current and Predicted. This VC is classified as Traditional and Innovative.   The type of innovation of this VC (Value Chain) is Endogenous and Exogenous. The cheese is moinly produced on farm with very few number of larger processors in the territory and thus a limited amount of product available for the market. For these reasons, producers are exploring alternative marketing strategies besides local markets, such as e-commerce and on farm selling (usually coupled with agritourism actvities). The innovation is related to New marketing strategies. The land use systems involved are Grassland, Forestry and Natural land. The local assets include Natural and cultural.   The VC is present within the two mountain areas present in the Province of Foggia (NUTS3: ) ('Gargano' and 'Monti Dauni')."

Risposta: "<think>
Alright, so I need to figure out if the mountain value chain described here is involved in producing cheese with a Protected Designation of Origin (PDO) certification. Let me go through the narrative step by step.

First, the narrative mentions that the cheese is called "Caciocavallo dei Monti Dauni" and it holds the label of 'Traditional Food Italian Product'. I know that PDO certification is similar to this in that it's a protected status for products with specific geographical origins. So, being labeled as a Traditional Food Italian Product might be related.

The narrative also states that there's a production specification scheme which requires using milk only from wild and semi-wild breed Podolica cows and traditional production techniques. This specificity is a key component of PDO certification because it ensures the product's unique characteristics are tied to its origin.

The complexity of productions and services could make the VC less competitive because milk and cheese are not certified as organic. More over, the production's territorial and historical identification is reported in a limited way. 'Latte del Parco' does not use all the potentialities of e-commerce. No links with other breeders are reported. Overall the type of challenge faced by this VC is Current and Predicted. This VC is classified as Traditional. The VC includes several processed products beyond the local dairy tradition (such as ice creams and parfaits from farm milk), and the farmer offers informative tourist services. The innovation is related to the whole VC. The land use systems involved are Cropland, Grassland and Natural land. The local assets include Natural and cultural."

The innovation start to spread also in this very traditional value chain. In fact, these cows live free on pasture from May to October, while for the remainder of the year they live in the large farm center feeding on hay from local fields, integrated with a mixture of cereals grown on the farm. Promp: "ID Narrative: 2884
The MOVING reference member state of this VC (Value Chain) is ITALY UNIMOL and UNIPI. The reference MOVING Card ID of this VC is VC 54 IT. The production of 'melga dei bobè' sees the harvest in the months of October and November, the ears are then opened, cleaned and hung on the attic to dry until the following spring, when they will be shelled and taken to the mill where the millstone, strictly in stone, returns a tasty and red corn flour, excellent for polenta and biscuits.   The reference mountain chain of this VC is Southern Alps - Brescia Prealps. The reference mountain landscape of this VC is Ceto. Muscoline is a municipality in the Italian province of Brescia, Lombardy. Located about 31 km East of chief city Brescia and 12 Km West of Garda lake.   The size of the area (km2) is 32.3. Promp: "ID Narrative: 2885
The MOVING reference member state of this VC (Value Chain) is GERMANY VINIDEA. The reference MOVING Card ID of this VC is VC 01 DE. The planted vineyard area is around 89 ha and is cultivated by 44 wineries - so the structures are quite small. Like the Moselle in general, Winningen is known for white wine (about 90% of the vineyard area) and especially for Riesling. Unlike other sections of the growing region, many more dry wines are produced here. This is thanks to the village's most famous winegrower Heymann-Löwenstein, who has been producing mainly dry wines since the early 1980s and was thus one of the pioneers on the Moselle. In 2005, one of his wines was named best foreign wine in Paris. He also worked to ensure that the 'Uhlen' vineyard was the first one in Germany to receive three small appellations contrôlées within only one vineyard.   The reference mountain chain of this VC is Rhenish Massif. The reference mountain landscape of this VC is Winningen. Winningen is located on the Lower Moselle only about 10 km from Koblenz, where the Moselle flows into the Rhine. Many years ago, terraces were built by hand in order to cultivate vines on the extremely steep slopes. The terroir is characterised by Devonian slate of various formations and is mainly known as the home of powerful Riesling wines, which in the 19th century were as expensive as the top crus from Bordeaux and Burgundy.   The size of the area (km2) is 6.65. The minimum altimetry of the LAU (Local Administrative Unit) is 75. The maximum altimetry of the LAU is 210. The total population (in thousand) is 2.421. The population density (Inhabitants/km2) in the LAU is 364. The population change rate of the LAU in the last 10 years (%) has been -1.80%. The overall regional population density (Inhabitants/km2) is 185.61. The regional population change rate in the last 10 years (%) has been 0.50%.   The average per capita income (EUR/year) [Province] is 34600. The total Gross Value Added (GVA) (EUR million/year) [Province] is 6043.8. The primary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 0.76%. The secondary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 36.27%. The tertiary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 62.96%. The per capita income (EUR/year) [Region] is 34600. The total Gross Value Added (GVA) (EUR million/year) [Region] is 45321.94. The primary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 0.88%. The secondary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 31.73%. The tertiary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 67.38%.   The total number of bed places (BPs) in tourist accommodations/year in the LAU (Local Administrative Unit) is 254. The regional (Region) share of total BPs/year is unspecified. The number of agricultural holdings in the LAU is 706. The nearest settlement with population over 100000 (km) is 10.2. In this region protected areas are present.   The primary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 1.24%. The secondary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 26.80%. The tertiary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 71.95%. The primary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 1.40%. The secondary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 26.28%. The tertiary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 72.33%.   Wines from extremely steep, terraced vineyards (70% slope) with low yields and high quality. The vineyards are characterised by many small plots with their own microclimates and different slate formations (red, blue and grey slate) and are habitats for rare animals such as the Apollo butterfly. Due to climate change, the comparatively warm slopes are heating up. The careful work of the winegrowers enhances the reputation of the wines and ensures a clear and unique style. They are distinguished from the rest of the Moselle wines by their mix of opulence and delicacy.   Winningen is located in a nature reserve. This winegrowing municipality has won several awards, making it one of the most beautiful villages in Germany. It is famous for the 'Moselfest', the oldest wine festival in Germany.    The vineyards cannot be mechanised. For many wines produced there, apart from a few well-known wineries, no adequate prices are achieved in relation to the production effort. Organic viticulture is therefore not or hardly possible. Overall the type of challenge faced by this VC is Current. This VC is classified as Traditional and Innovative.   The type of innovation of this VC (Value Chain) is unspecified. For some years now, the municipality has been receiving more attention through the activities of the young generation of winemakers. In 2020, a young winemaker from Winningen was named Rising Star of the Year by Germany's most important wine guide. The innovation is related to New processes and New marketing strategies. The land use systems involved are Cropland and Vineyard area. The local assets include Natural and Cultural.   Comparable terraced vineyards can be found in particular on the Moselle and its tributaries the Saar and Ruwer. The most famous example is certainly the 'Calmont' in the village of Bremm, which is the steepest vineyard in Europe. In addition, terraces have also been created in other mountainous regions such as Baden, Rheingau and the Middle Rhine."

The vineyard was planted and is now in production, still to be assessed the consequences of quality and the response to climate change (it needs longer periods).   The reference mountain chain of this VC is Eastern Alps. The reference mountain landscape of this VC is Trento. Trento is the capital of Trentino Autonomous province. Promp: "ID Narrative: 2889
The MOVING reference member state of this VC (Value Chain) is ITALY VINIDEA. The reference MOVING Card ID of this VC is VC 26 IT. Key activities of the VC are vine growing and wine production. The vineyard of Aosta Valley consists of just under 23,5 ha of which more than 18 ha belong to the members of the cooperative 'Cave Mont Blanc', and other 5,5 ha belong to 3 individual wine producers. A peculiarity of local viticulture is the great fragmentation of the cultivated area in small plots of land. Individual wine producers, grape producers, who sell grapes to cooperatives, and the cooperative winery are the key actors of this small value chain. In the last thirty years the wines of Valle d'Aosta have had a remarkable growth in quality, witnessed by the numerous awards at national and international level both in oenological competitions and by guides and magazines. About 70% of the production is consumed locally, thanks to the presence of a flourishing tourist activity that brings more than three million visitors to Valle d'Aosta every year. A share between 10% and 20% is destined for sale in other Italian regions, while the remaining share is destined for export. If, on the one hand, the oenological offer, very fragmented and small in size, does not favor large-scale marketing, on the other hand it finds space in a niche market in search of products on which to boast exclusivity.   The reference mountain chain of this VC is Western Alps. The reference mountain landscape of this VC is Morgex. Morgex and La Salle are located in the upper Aosta Valley, at the entrance to Valdigne. The municipalities are crossed by the Dora Baltea river and dominated by Mount Paramont (3 300 m) to the south and La Grande Rochère (3 326 m) to the north.The Aosta Valley is a mountainous autonomous region in north-western Italy. Covering an area of 3,263 km2 and with a population of about 128,000 it is the smallest, least populous, and least densely populated region of Italy. The valley is very attractive for tourist for winter sports and for hiking in summer.   The size of the area (km2) is 127.57. The minimum altimetry of the LAU (Local Administrative Unit) is 780. The maximum altimetry of the LAU is 3326. The total population (in thousand) is 4. The population density (Inhabitants/km2) in the LAU is 31.4. The population change rate of the LAU in the last 10 years (%) has been 3.00%. The overall regional population density (Inhabitants/km2) is 38.5. The regional population change rate in the last 10 years (%) has been 0.18%.   The average per capita income (EUR/year) [Province] is 16857.5. The total Gross Value Added (GVA) (EUR million/year) [Province] is 4330.8. The primary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 1.20%. The secondary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 18.40%. The tertiary sector share of total GVA/year [Province] is 80.40%. The per capita income (EUR/year) [Region] is 16572. The total Gross Value Added (GVA) (EUR million/year) [Region] is 4330.8. The primary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 1.20%. The secondary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 18.40%. The tertiary sector share of total GVA/year [Region] is 80.40%.   The total number of bed places (BPs) in tourist accommodations/year in the LAU (Local Administrative Unit) is 57883. The regional (Region) share of total BPs/year is 1.13%. The number of agricultural holdings in the LAU is 242. The nearest settlement with population over 100000 (km) is 140. In this region protected areas are present.   The primary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 3.00%. The secondary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 21.00%. The tertiary sector share of total employment/year [Province] is 76.00%. The primary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 3.00%. The secondary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 21.00%. The tertiary sector share of total employment/year [Region] is 76.00%.   Wine produced under the denomination of origin 'Vallée d'Aoste Blanc de Morgex et de La Salle DOC' is made from grapes harvested in the highest vineyards in Europe, at the foot of the Mont Blanc massif. Prié Blanc is the variety used for its production and is the only indigenous white grape variety of the Valle d'Aosta. This VC is relevant to the project as an example of a quality boost of mountain viticulture, which offers a high reputation product for local consumers and numerous tourists and contributes to the landscape identity of the Region.   The main resource of Valdostan viticulture lies in the local native vine varieties, grown only in the valley. Many native grape varieties, as part of the Valdostan culture, have recently been selected and replanted. The Prié Blanc, the only native white-berried variety, is one of the rare varieties not grafted onto American vines thanks to special climate conditions that have preserved them from phylloxera. Versatility of this variety allows to produce high quality wines of different types: sparkling wine, dry still wine and sweet dessert wine made from late harvest grapes. The vines are grown on terraces supported by dry stone walls, on embankments or, where possible, in the direction of the slope. Given the features of the terrain and the low rainfall in the area, it is not necessary to take any particular measures to channel and control surface water.    One of the main challenges for viticulture in the municipalities of Morgex et la Salle are the extremely high altitude for vines (above 1200 m), which creates constant risk of frost all over the growing season which in one night take away the hall harvest in one night. Another important problem to be overcome, particularly for mountain winegrowing, is that of increasing the surface under vineyards in order to be more present on the market. (At present, the vineyard surface for prodution of wines with the denomination of originis around 270 ha throughout the region, 24,5 ha belong to the Mountain Reference Lanscape of Morgex et La Salle). Overall the type of challenge faced by this VC is Current and Predicted. This VC is classified as Traditional.   The type of innovation of this VC (Value Chain) is unspecified. The innovation is related to the whole VC. The land use systems involved are Cropland and vineyards. The local assets include Natural and cultural.   The VC is also present in other MRLs in Italy, Spain, Portugal, Austria and Germany."

Promp: "ID Narrative: 2890
The MOVING reference member state of this VC (Value Chain) is ITALY VINIDEA. The reference MOVING Card ID of this VC is VC 29 IT. The viticultural activity on the island is performed by a small number of individual wine producers mostly concentrated on the production of sweet wine. As this type of wine is not easy to commercialise, an innovative wine producer decides to amplify his production introducing high quality dry wines. At the same time he implements a new marketing strategy leaning on the huge touristic flow in the area offering a possibility to stay in a modern wine resort and numerous tailor-made tasting and gastronomic experiences. The wine is distributed in the folowing main channels: private clients (tourists), e-commerce and export.   The reference mountain chain of this VC is Aeolian Islands. The reference mountain landscape of this VC is Lipari. Lipari is the largest of a chain of the Aeolian islands in a volcanic archipelago situated in between Vesuvius and Etna in the Tyrrhenian Sea off the northern coast of Sicily, southern Italy. As a result of its volcanic origin, the island is covered with pumice and obsidian. From April till October the area receives an important touristic flow.   The size of the area (km2) is 89.72. The minimum altimetry of the LAU (Local Administrative Unit) is 0. The maximum altimetry of the LAU is 602. The total population (in thousand) is 12.5. Traditional wine produced in the island under the denomination 'Malvasia delle Lipari' is a sweet dessert wine from the dried Malvasia grapes The main actor of the VC introduced a range of high quality dry wines using Corinto Nero variety with was on the verge of the extinction. He also implemented new marketing strategies adressed to massive touristic flow on the island.   Key local assets involve mainly specific lanscape and scenary, sea resorts and unique geological formations as Kaolin Quarries which are attractive for tourists from Italy and abroad. The main resources for the local viticulture are the autochnotous grape varieties (Malvasia and Corinto Nero) and volcanic soils, having specific characteristics valuable for wine production.    A common challenge for small island viticulture is the isolation from the main land which causes extremely high cost of production. Steep slopes and traditional type of pruning makes mechanization impractical and requires a lot of manual operations. Overall the type of challenge faced by this VC is Predicted. This VC is classified as Traditional and Innovative.   The type of innovation of this VC (Value Chain) is Endogenous and Exogenous. First innovation of this VC is the return to using of an abandoned autochtonous variety from the area, recuperated thanks to mass and clonal selection. Second innovation is the implementation of a high-level wine resort in the middle of the vineyards and offering a wide range of tasting and gastronomic activities. The innovation is related to New products and New marketing strategies. The land use systems involved are Cropland, natural land and Vineyard and other cultures in the area as olive trees and cappers. The local assets include Natural."

Later, the use of oak wood casks for Nerello fining, was optimzing the intrinsec quality of the red wines. In the last 15 years took place an increasing adoption of organic, biodynamic, natural, and quantic standards for production.
